Parts.Title: Concerning God
Parts.Focus: Metaphysics of substance, attributes, and modes
Key Definitions: By cause of itself I understand that whose essence involves existence, or that whose nature cannot be conceived except as existing
By substance I understand that which is in itself and is conceived through itself
By attribute I understand that which the intellect perceives of substance as constituting its essence
By mode I understand the affections of substance, or that which is in another through which it is also conceived
By God I understand an absolutely infinite being, that is, a substance consisting of infinite attributes, each of which expresses eternal and infinite essence
Key Axioms: All things that are, are either in themselves or in another
The knowledge of an effect depends on, and involves, the knowledge of the cause
From a given determinate cause the effect follows necessarily; and, conversely, if there is no determinate cause, it is impossible for an effect to follow

Key Propositions.Statement: Substance is by nature prior to its modifications.
Key Propositions.Significance: Establishes the ontological priority of substance over its modes

Key Propositions.Statement: Two substances, whose attributes are different, have nothing in common.
Key Propositions.Significance: Shows that distinct substances cannot share attributes

Key Propositions.Statement: Things which have nothing in common cannot be one the cause of the other.
Key Propositions.Significance: Prevents causal interaction between unrelated substances

Key Propositions.Statement: Two or more distinct things are distinguished one from the other, either by the difference of the attributes of the substances, or by the difference of their modifications.
Key Propositions.Significance: Defines the basis for distinguishing distinct entities

Key Propositions.Statement: There cannot exist in the universe two or more substances having the same nature or attribute.
Key Propositions.Significance: Ensures uniqueness of substances sharing attributes

Key Propositions.Statement: One substance cannot be produced by another substance.
Key Propositions.Significance: Substances are uncaused by other substances

Key Propositions.Statement: Existence belongs to the nature of substances.
Key Propositions.Significance: Substances necessarily exist by their essence

Key Propositions.Statement: Every substance is necessarily infinite.
The more reality or being a thing has, the greater the number of its attributes.
Key Propositions.Significance: Links degree of reality to number of attributes

Key Propositions.Statement: Each particular attribute of the one substance must be conceived through itself.
God, or a substance consisting of infinite attributes, each of which expresses eternal and infinite essence, necessarily exists
No attribute of substance can be conceived from which it would follow that substance can be divided.
Key Propositions.Significance: Substance cannot be divided based on its attributes

Key Propositions.Statement: Substance absolutely infinite is indivisible.
Key Propositions.Significance: Infinite substance is one and undivided

Key Propositions.Statement: Except God, no substance can be or be conceived
Key Propositions.Significance: Establishes monism: God is the only substance

Key Propositions.Statement: Whatever is, is in God, and nothing can be or be conceived without God
Key Propositions.Significance: Pantheism: All things are modes of God

Key Propositions.Statement: From the necessity of the divine nature must follow an infinite number of things in infinite ways—that is, all things which can fall within the sphere of infinite intellect.
Key Propositions.Significance: Infinite things follow from God's nature

Key Propositions.Statement: God acts solely by the laws of his own nature, and is not constrained by anyone.
God is the indwelling and not the transient cause of all things.
God, and all the attributes of God, are eternal.
The existence of God and his essence are one and the same.
All things which follow from the absolute nature of any attribute of God must always exist and be infinite, or, in other words, are eternal and infinite through the said attribute.
Key Propositions.Significance: Things following from attributes are eternal and infinite

Key Propositions.Statement: Whatsoever follows from any attribute of God, in so far as it is modified by a modification, which exists necessarily and as infinite, through the said attribute, must also exist necessarily and as infinite.
Key Propositions.Significance: Necessary existence of modifications from infinite modes

Key Propositions.Statement: Every mode, which exists both necessarily and as infinite, must necessarily follow either from the absolute nature of some attribute of God, or from an attribute modified by a modification which exists necessarily, and as infinite.
The essence of things produced by God does not involve existence.
Key Propositions.Significance: Modes do not have existence in their essence

Key Propositions.Statement: God is the efficient cause not only of the existence of things, but also of their essence.
Key Propositions.Significance: God causes both essence and existence

Key Propositions.Statement: A thing which is conditioned to act in a particular manner, has necessarily been thus conditioned by God; and that which has not been conditioned by God cannot condition itself to act.
A thing, which has been conditioned by God to act in a particular way, cannot render itself unconditioned.

Every individual thing, or everything which is finite and has a conditioned existence, cannot exist or be conditioned to act, unless it be conditioned for existence and action by a cause other than itself, which also is finite, and has a conditioned existence; and likewise this cause cannot in its turn exist, or be conditioned to act, unless it be conditioned for existence and action by another cause, which also is finite, and has a conditioned existence, and so on to infinity.
Key Propositions.Significance: Chain of finite causes to infinity

Key Propositions.Statement: Nothing in the universe is contingent, but all things are conditioned to exist and operate in a particular manner by the necessity of the divine nature.
Key Propositions.Significance: Rejection of contingency in the universe

Key Propositions.Statement: Intellect, in function (actu) finite, or in function infinite, must comprehend the attributes of God and the modifications of God, and nothing else.
Key Propositions.Significance: Scope of intellect limited to God's attributes and modes

Key Propositions.Statement: The intellect in function, whether finite or infinite, as will, desire, love, &c., should be referred to passive nature and not to active nature.
Will cannot be called a free cause, but only a necessary cause.
Things could not have been brought into being by God in any manner or in any order different from that which has in fact obtained.
God's power is identical with his essence.
Key Propositions.Significance: Power and essence unified in God

Key Propositions.Statement: Whatsoever we conceive to be in the power of God, necessarily exists.
There is no cause from whose nature some effect does not follow.

Parts.Summary: Argues that God is the unique, infinite substance with infinite attributes (thought and extension known to humans), and all else are modes dependent on God

Parts.Title: Of the Nature and Origin of the Mind
Key Definitions: The essence of man consists in certain modifications of the attributes of God
By idea I understand a conception of the Mind which the Mind forms because it is a thinking thing
Key Axioms: The modes of thinking, such as love, desire, or whatever emotions are designated by the name of affects, do not occur unless there is in the same individual the idea of the thing loved, desired, etc.

Key Propositions.Statement: Thought is an attribute of God, or God is a thinking thing.
Extension is an attribute of God, or God is an extended thing.
In God there is necessarily the idea not only of his essence, but also of all things which necessarily follow from his essence.
The idea of God, from which an infinite number of things follow in infinite ways, can only be one.

The actual being of ideas owns God as its cause, only in so far as he is considered as a thinking thing, not in so far as he is unfolded in any other attribute; that is, the ideas both of the attributes of God and of particular things do not own as their efficient cause their objects (ideata) or the things perceived, but God himself in so far as he is a thinking thing.
Key Propositions.Significance: God as cause of ideas through thought

Key Propositions.Statement: The modes of any given attribute are caused by God, in so far as he is considered through the attribute of which they are modes, and not in so far as he is considered through any other attribute.
The order and connection of ideas is the same as the order and connection of things

The ideas of particular things, or of modes, that do not exist, must be comprehended in the infinite idea of God, in the same way as the formal essences of particular things or modes are contained in the attributes of God.
Key Propositions.Significance: Ideas of non-existent modes in God

Key Propositions.Statement: The idea of an individual thing actually existing is caused by God, not in so far as he is infinite, but in so far as he is considered as affected by another idea of a thing actually existing, of which he is the cause, in so far as he is affected by a third idea, and so on to infinity.
Key Propositions.Significance: Causation of ideas of existing things

Key Propositions.Statement: The being of substance does not appertain to the essence of man—in other words, substance does not constitute the actual being of man.
The first thing that constitutes the actual being of a human Mind is nothing but the idea of a singular thing which actually exists
Key Propositions.Significance: Mind as the idea of the body

Key Propositions.Statement: Whatsoever comes to pass in the object of the idea, which constitutes the human mind, must be perceived by the human mind, or there will necessarily be an idea in the human mind of the said occurrence. That is, if the object of the idea constituting the human mind be a body, nothing can take place in that body without being perceived by the mind.
The object of the idea constituting the human mind is the body, in other words a certain mode of extension which actually exists, and nothing else.
Key Propositions.Significance: Body as object of the mind

Key Propositions.Statement: The human mind is capable of perceiving a great number of things, and is so in proportion as its body is capable of receiving a great number of impressions.
Key Propositions.Significance: Mind's perception tied to body's capacity

Key Propositions.Statement: The idea, which constitutes the actual being of the human mind, is not simple, but compounded of a great number of ideas.
The idea of every mode, in which the human body is affected by external bodies, must involve the nature of the human body, and also the nature of the external body.
Key Propositions.Significance: Ideas involve natures of body and externals

Key Propositions.Statement: If the human body is affected in a manner which involves the nature of any external body, the human mind will regard the said external body as actually existing, or as present to itself, until the human body be affected in such a way, as to exclude the existence or the presence of the said external body.
If the human body has once been affected by two or more bodies at the same time, when the mind afterwards imagines any of them, it will straightway remember the others also.
Key Propositions.Significance: Association of ideas through simultaneous affection

Key Propositions.Statement: The human mind has no knowledge of the body, and does not know it to exist, save through the ideas of the modifications whereby the body is affected.
Key Propositions.Significance: Knowledge of body through ideas of affections

Key Propositions.Statement: The idea or knowledge of the human mind is also in God, following in God in the same manner, and being referred to God in the same manner, as the idea or knowledge of the human body.
This idea of the mind is united to the mind in the same way as the mind is united to the body.
Key Propositions.Significance: Union of idea of mind to mind

Key Propositions.Statement: The human mind perceives not only the modifications of the body, but also the ideas of such modifications.
The mind does not know itself, except in so far as it perceives the ideas of the modifications of the body.
The human mind does not involve an adequate knowledge of the parts composing the human body.
The idea of each modification of the human body does not involve an adequate knowledge of the external body.
The human mind does not perceive any external body as actually existing, except through the ideas of the modifications of its
Key Propositions.Significance: Perception of externals through body modifications

Key Propositions.Statement: The idea of each modification of the human body does not involve an adequate knowledge of the human body itself.
The ideas of the modifications of the human body, in so far as they have reference only to the human mind, are not clear and distinct, but confused.
The idea of the idea of each modification of the human body does not involve an adequate knowledge of the human mind.
We can only have a very inadequate knowledge of the duration of our body.
We can only have a very inadequate knowledge of the duration of particular things external to ourselves.
All ideas, in so far as they are referred to God, are true.
There is nothing positive in ideas, which causes them to be called false.
Every idea, which in us is absolute or adequate and perfect, is true.
Falsity consists in the privation of knowledge, which inadequate, fragmentary, or confused ideas involve.
Inadequate and confused ideas follow by the same necessity, as adequate or clear and distinct ideas.
That which is common to all (cf. Lemma II., above), and which is equally in a part and in the whole, does not constitute the essence of any particular thing.
Those things, which are common to all, and which are equally in a part and in the whole, cannot be conceived except adequately.

That, which is common to and a property of the human body and such other bodies as are wont to affect the human body, and which is present equally in each part of either, or in the whole, will be represented by an adequate idea in the mind.
Whatsoever ideas in the mind follow from ideas which are therein adequate, are also themselves adequate.
Knowledge of the first kind is the only source of falsity, knowledge of the second and third kinds is necessarily true.
Key Propositions.Significance: Sources of truth and falsity in knowledge kinds

Key Propositions.Statement: Knowledge of the second and third kinds, not knowledge of the first kind, teaches us to distinguish the true from the false.
He, who has a true idea, simultaneously knows that he has a true idea, and cannot doubt of the truth of the thing perceived.
It is not in the nature of reason to regard things as contingent, but as necessary.
Every idea of every body, or of every particular thing actually existing, necessarily involves the eternal and infinite essence of God.
The knowledge of the eternal and infinite essence of God which every idea involves is adequate and perfect.
The human mind has an adequate knowledge of the eternal and infinite essence of God.
In the Mind there is no absolute, or free, will, but the Mind is determined to will this or that by a cause which is also determined by another, and this again by another, and so to infinity
Key Propositions.Significance: Denial of free will in the traditional sense

Key Propositions.Statement: There is in the mind no volition or affirmation and negation, save that which an idea, inasmuch as it is an idea, involves.

Parts.Summary: Explains the mind as a mode of the attribute of thought, parallel to the body as a mode of extension; introduces three kinds of knowledge: imagination, reason, and intuitive knowledge

Parts.Title: Of the Origin and Nature of the Affects
Key Postulates: The human Body can be affected in many ways by which its power of acting is increased or diminished
The human Body can undergo many changes, and nevertheless retain impressions or traces of objects
Key Definitions: By affect I understand affections of the Body by which the Body's power of acting is increased or diminished, aided or restrained, and at the same time, the ideas of these affections

Key Propositions.Statement: Our mind is in certain cases active, and in certain cases passive. In so far as it has adequate ideas it is necessarily active, and in so far as it has inadequate ideas, it is necessarily passive.
Key Propositions.Significance: Mind's activity and passivity based on ideas

Key Propositions.Statement: Body cannot determine mind to think, neither can mind determine body to motion or rest or any state different from these, if such there be.
Key Propositions.Significance: No direct causation between body and mind

Key Propositions.Statement: The activities of the mind arise solely from adequate ideas; the passive states of the mind depend solely on inadequate ideas.
Key Propositions.Significance: Source of active and passive states

Key Propositions.Statement: Nothing can be destroyed, except by a cause external to itself.
Things are naturally contrary, that is, cannot exist in the same object, in so far as one is capable of destroying the other.
Each thing, as far as it can by its own power, strives to persevere in its being
The endeavour, wherewith everything endeavours to persist in its own being, is nothing else but the actual essence of the thing in question.
The endeavour, whereby a thing endeavours to persist in its own being, involves no finite time, but an indefinite time.

The mind, both in so far as it has clear and distinct ideas, and also in so far as it has confused ideas, endeavours to persist in its being for an indefinite period, and of this endeavour it is conscious.
An idea, which excludes the existence of our body, cannot be postulated in our mind, but is contrary thereto.
Key Propositions.Significance: Incompatibility of ideas denying body's existence

Key Propositions.Statement: The idea of any thing that increases or diminishes, aids or restrains, our Body's power of acting, increases or diminishes, aids or restrains, our Mind's power of thinking
Key Propositions.Significance: Basis for defining pleasure and pain

Key Propositions.Statement: The mind, as far as it can, endeavours to conceive those things, which increase or help the power of activity in the body.
When the mind conceives things which diminish or hinder the body's power of activity, it endeavours, as far as possible, to remember things which exclude the existence of the first-named things.
If the mind has once been affected by two emotions at the same time, it will, whenever it is afterwards affected by one of these two, be also affected by the other.
Anything can, accidentally, be the cause of pleasure, pain, or desire.

Simply from the fact that we conceive, that a given object has some point of resemblance with another object which is wont to affect the mind pleasurably or painfully, although the point of resemblance be not the efficient cause of the said emotions, we shall still regard the first-named object with love or hate.

If we conceive that a thing, which is wont to affect us painfully, has any point of resemblance with another thing which is wont to affect us with an equally strong emotion of pleasure, we shall hate the first-named thing, and at the same time we shall love it.
A man is as much affected pleasurably or painfully by the image of a thing past or future as by the image of a thing present.
Key Propositions.Significance: Affects from past or future images

Key Propositions.Statement: He who conceives that the object of his love is destroyed will feel pain; if he conceives that it is preserved he will feel pleasure.
He who conceives that the object of his hate is destroyed will also feel pleasure.

He who conceives, that the object of his love is affected pleasurably or painfully, will himself be affected pleasurably or painfully; and the one or the other emotion will be greater or less in the lover according as it is greater or less in the thing loved.

If we conceive that anything pleasurably affects some object of our love, we shall be affected with love towards that thing. Contrariwise, if we conceive that it affects an object of our love painfully, we shall be affected with hatred towards it.
Key Propositions.Significance: Love or hate based on effect on loved object

Key Propositions.Statement: He who conceives, that an object of his hatred is painfully affected, will feel pleasure. Contrariwise, if he thinks that the said object is pleasurably affected, he will feel pain. Each of these emotions will be greater or less, according as its contrary is greater or less in the object of hatred.
If we conceive that anyone pleasurably affects an object of our hate, we shall feel hatred towards him also. If we conceive that he painfully affects that said object, we shall feel love towards him.
Key Propositions.Significance: Affects toward those affecting hated objects

Key Propositions.Statement: We endeavour to affirm, concerning ourselves, and concerning what we love, everything that we can conceive to affect pleasurably ourselves, or the loved object. Contrariwise, we endeavour to negative everything, which we conceive to affect painfully ourselves or the
Key Propositions.Significance: Affirmation of pleasurable for self and loved

Key Propositions.Statement: We endeavour to affirm, concerning that which we hate, everything which we conceive to affect it painfully; and, contrariwise, we endeavour to deny, concerning it, everything which we conceive to affect it pleasurably.

By the very fact that we conceive a thing, which is like ourselves, and which we have not regarded with any emotion, to be affected with any emotion, we are ourselves affected with a like emotion (affectus).
We endeavour to bring about whatsoever we conceive to conduce to pleasure; but we endeavour to remove or destroy whatsoever we conceive to be truly repugnant thereto, or to conduce to pain.
We shall also endeavour to do whatsoever we conceive men to regard with pleasure, and contrariwise we shall shrink from doing that which we conceive men to shrink from.

If anyone has done something which he conceives as affecting other men pleasurably, he will be affected by pleasure, accompanied by the idea of himself as cause; in other words, he will regard himself with pleasure. On the other hand, if he has done anything which he conceives as affecting others painfully, he will regard himself with pain.
Key Propositions.Significance: Self-regard from perceived effects on others

Key Propositions.Statement: If we conceive that anyone loves, desires, or hates anything which we ourselves love, desire, or hate, we shall thereupon regard the thing in question with more steadfast love, &c. On the contrary, if we think that anyone shrinks from something that we love, we shall undergo vacillations of soul.
Key Propositions.Significance: Reinforcement or vacillation from others' affects

Key Propositions.Statement: If we conceive that anyone takes delight in something, which only one person can possess, we shall endeavour to bring it about that the man in question shall not gain possession thereof.
When we love a thing similar to ourselves we endeavour, as far as we can, to bring about that it should love us in return.
The greater the emotion with which we conceive a loved object to be affected towards us, the greater will be our complacency.

If anyone conceives, that an object of his love joins itself to another with closer bonds of friendship than he himself has attained to, he will be affected with hatred towards the loved object and with envy towards his rival.
He who remembers a thing, in which he has once taken delight, desires to possess it under the same circumstances as when he first took delight therein.
Desire arising through pain or pleasure, hatred or love, is greater in proportion as the emotion is greater.

If a man has begun to hate an object of his love, so that love is thoroughly destroyed, he will, causes being equal, regard it with more hatred than if he had never loved it, and his hatred will be in proportion to the strength of his former love.

He who hates anyone will endeavour to do him an injury, unless he fears that a greater injury will thereby accrue to himself; on the other hand, he who loves anyone will, by the same law, seek to benefit him.
He, who conceives himself to be hated by another, and believes that he has given him no cause for hatred, will hate that other in return.
If anyone conceives that he is loved by another, and believes that he has given no cause for such love, he will love that other in return. (Cf. III. xv. Coroll., and III. xvi.)
He who has conferred a benefit on anyone from motives of love or honour will feel pain, if he sees that the benefit is received without gratitude.
Hatred is increased by being reciprocated, and can on the other hand be destroyed by love.
Hatred which is completely vanquished by love passes into love: and love is thereupon greater than if hatred had not preceded it.
Key Propositions.Significance: Transformation of hatred to stronger love

Key Propositions.Statement: If a man conceives, that anyone similar to himself hates anything also similar to himself, which he loves, he will hate that person.
Key Propositions.Significance: Hate from shared hate toward loved

Key Propositions.Statement: If a man has been affected pleasurably or painfully by anyone, of a class or nation different from his own, and if the pleasure or pain has been accompanied by the idea of the said stranger as cause, under the general category of the class or nation: the man will feel love or hatred, not only to the individual stranger, but also to the whole class or nation whereto he belongs.
Joy arising from the fact, that anything we hate is destroyed, or suffers other injury, is never unaccompanied by a certain pain in us.
Love or hatred towards, for instance, Peter is destroyed, if the pleasure involved in the former
Key Propositions.Significance: Destruction of affects by removing cause

Key Propositions.Statement: Love or hatred towards a thing, which we conceive to be free, must, other conditions being similar, be greater than if it were felt towards a thing acting by necessity.
Anything whatever can be, accidentally, a cause of hope or fear.
Key Propositions.Significance: Accidental causes of hope and fear

Key Propositions.Statement: Different men may be differently affected by the same object, and the same man may be differently affected at different times by the same object.

An object which we have formerly seen in conjunction with others, and which we do not conceive to have any property that is not common to many, will not be regarded by us for so long, as an object which we conceive to have some property peculiar to itself.

When the mind regards itself and its own power of activity, it feels pleasure: and that pleasure is greater in proportion to the distinctness wherewith it conceives itself and its own power of activity.
The mind endeavours to conceive only such things as assert its power of activity.
When the mind contemplates its own weakness, it feels pain thereat.

There are as many kinds of pleasure, of pain, of desire, and of every emotion compounded of these, such as vacillations of spirit, or derived from these, such as love, hatred, hope, fear, &c., as there are kinds of objects whereby we are affected.
Any emotion of a given individual differs from the emotion of another individual, only in so far as the essence of the one individual differs from the essence of the other.
Besides pleasure and desire, which are passivities or passions, there are other emotions derived from pleasure and desire, which are attributable to us in so far as we are active.
Key Propositions.Significance: Active emotions from pleasure and desire

Key Propositions.Statement: Among all the emotions attributable to the mind as active, there are none which cannot be referred to pleasure or desire.
Key Propositions.Significance: All active emotions reduce to pleasure or desire

Parts.Summary: Analyzes emotions (affects) as transitions in the body's power, classifying them into active and passive, with primary affects being desire, joy, and sadness

Parts.Title: Of Human Bondage, or the Powers of the Affects
Key Definitions: Good: That which we certainly know to be useful to us
Evil: That which we certainly know prevents us from being masters of some good
Key Axioms: There is no singular thing in nature than which there is not another more powerful and stronger

Key Propositions.Statement: Nothing positive which a false idea has is removed by the presence of the true insofar as it is true
We are only passive, in so far as we are a part of Nature, which cannot be conceived by itself without other parts.
The force whereby a man persists in existing is limited, and is infinitely surpassed by the power of external causes.
It is impossible, that man should not be a part of Nature, or that he should be capable of undergoing no changes, save such as can be understood through his nature only as their adequate cause.
Key Propositions.Significance: Man as part of nature, subject to changes

Key Propositions.Statement: The power and increase of every passion, and its persistence in existing are not defined by the power, whereby we ourselves endeavour to persist in existing, but by the power of an external cause compared with our own.
The force of any passion or emotion can overcome the rest of a man's activities or power, so that the emotion becomes obstinately fixed to him.
An emotion can only be controlled or destroyed by another emotion contrary thereto, and with more power for controlling emotion.
Key Propositions.Significance: Control of emotions by stronger contrary emotions

Key Propositions.Statement: The knowledge of good and evil is nothing else but the emotions of pleasure or pain, in so far as we are conscious thereof.
An emotion, whereof we conceive the cause to be with us at the present time, is stronger than if we did not conceive the cause to be with us.

Towards something future, which we conceive as close at hand, we are affected more intensely, than if we conceive that its time for existence is separated from the present by a longer interval; so too by the remembrance of what we conceive to have not long passed away we are affected more intensely, than if we conceive that it has long passed away.
An emotion towards that which we conceive as necessary is, when other conditions are equal, more intense than an emotion towards that which possible, or contingent, or non-necessary.

An emotion towards a thing, which we know not to exist at the present time, and which we conceive as possible, is more intense, other conditions being equal, than an emotion towards a thing contingent.
Emotion towards a thing contingent, which we know not to exist in the present, is, other conditions being equal, fainter than an emotion towards a thing past.
A true knowledge of good and evil cannot check any emotion by virtue of being true, but only in so far as it is considered as an emotion.
Desire arising from the knowledge of good and bad can be quenched or checked by many of the other desires arising from the emotions whereby we are assailed.

Desire arising from the knowledge of good and evil, in so far as such knowledge regards what is future, may be more easily controlled or quenched, than the desire for what is agreeable at the present moment.

In so far as men are a prey to passion, they cannot, in that respect, be said to be naturally in harmony.

Parts.Title: Of the Power of the Intellect, or of Human Freedom
Key Axioms: The affections of the Body, or images of things, are arranged and connected in the Body in exactly the same way as thoughts and ideas of things are arranged and connected in the Mind

Key Propositions.Statement: Even as thoughts and the ideas of things are arranged and associated in the mind, so are the modifications of body or the images of things precisely in the same way arranged and associated in the body.
Key Propositions.Significance: Parallel arrangement in mind and body

Key Propositions.Statement: If we remove a disturbance of the spirit, or emotion, from the thought of an external cause, and unite it to other thoughts, then will the love or hatred towards that external cause, and also the vacillations of spirit which arise from these emotions, be destroyed.
Key Propositions.Significance: Remedy by separating emotion from cause

Key Propositions.Statement: An emotion, which is a passion, ceases to be a passion, as soon as we form a clear and distinct idea thereof.
There is no modification of the body, whereof we cannot form some clear and distinct conception.
Key Propositions.Significance: Possible clarity for all body modifications

Key Propositions.Statement: An emotion towards a thing, which we conceive simply, and not as necessary, or as contingent, or as possible, is, other conditions being equal, greater than any other emotion.
The mind has greater power over the emotions and is less subject thereto, in so far as it understands all things as necessary.
Emotions which are aroused or spring from reason, if we take account of time, are stronger than those, which are attributable to particular objects that we regard as absent.
Key Propositions.Significance: Strength of rational emotions over time

Key Propositions.Statement: An emotion is stronger in proportion to the number of simultaneous concurrent causes whereby it is aroused.

An emotion, which is attributable to many and diverse causes which the mind regards as simultaneous with the emotion itself, is less hurtful, and we are less subject thereto and less affected towards each of its causes, than if it were a different and equally powerful emotion attributable to fewer causes or to a single cause.
So long as we are not assailed by emotions contrary to our nature, we have the power of arranging and associating the modifications of our body according to the intellectual order.
In proportion as a mental image is referred to more objects, so is it more frequent, or more often vivid, and occupies the mind more.
The mental images of things are more easily associated with the images referred to things which we clearly and distinctly understand, than with others.
A mental image is more often vivid, in proportion as it is associated with a greater number of other images.
The mind can bring it about, that all bodily modifications or images of things may be referred to the idea of God.
He who clearly and distinctly understands himself and his emotions loves God, and so much the more in proportion as he more understands himself and his emotions.
Key Propositions.Significance: Self-understanding leads to love of God

Key Propositions.Statement: This love towards God must hold the chief place in the mind.
God is without passions, neither is he affected by any emotion of pleasure or pain.
No one can hate God.
He, who loves God, cannot endeavour that God should love him in return.
Key Propositions.Significance: No desire for reciprocal love from God

Key Propositions.Statement: This love towards God cannot be stained by the emotion of envy or jealousy: contrariwise, it is the more fostered, in proportion as we conceive a greater number of men to be joined to God by the same bond of love.
The mind can only imagine anything, or remember what is past, while the body endures.
Key Propositions.Significance: Imagination and memory tied to body

Key Propositions.Statement: Nevertheless in God there is necessarily an idea, which expresses the essence of this or that human body under the form of eternity.
Key Propositions.Significance: Eternal idea of body in God

Key Propositions.Statement: The human mind cannot be absolutely destroyed with the body, but there remains of it something which is eternal.
Key Propositions.Significance: Eternity of part of the mind

Key Propositions.Statement: The more we understand particular things, the more do we understand God.
The highest endeavour of the mind, and the highest virtue is to understand things by the third kind of knowledge.
In proportion as the mind is more capable of understanding things by the third kind of knowledge, it desires more to understand things by that kind.
From this third kind of knowledge arises the highest possible mental acquiescence.
The endeavour or desire to know things by the third kind of knowledge cannot arise from the first, but from the second kind of knowledge.

Whatsoever the mind understands under the form of eternity, it does not understand by virtue of conceiving the present actual existence of the body, but by virtue of conceiving the essence of the body under the form of eternity.
Key Propositions.Significance: Eternal understanding independent of body's existence

Key Propositions.Statement: Our mind, in so far as it knows itself and the body under the form of eternity, has to that extent necessarily a knowledge of God, and knows that it is in God, and is conceived through God.
The third kind of knowledge depends on the mind, as its formal cause
Key Propositions.Significance: Mind as cause of intuitive knowledge

Key Propositions.Statement: Whatsoever we understand by the third kind of knowledge, we take delight in, and our delight is accompanied by the idea of God as cause.
Key Propositions.Significance: Delight in intuitive knowledge with God

Key Propositions.Statement: The intellectual love of God, which arises from the third kind of knowledge, is eternal.
The mind is, only while the body endures, subject to those emotions which are attributable to passions.
God loves himself with an infinite intellectual love.

The intellectual love of the mind towards God is that very love of God whereby God loves himself, not in so far as he is infinite, but in so far as he can be explained through the essence of the human mind regarded under the form of eternity; in other words, the intellectual love of the mind towards God is part of the infinite love wherewith God loves himself.
Key Propositions.Significance: Mind's love as part of God's love

Key Propositions.Statement: There is nothing in nature, which is contrary to this intellectual love, or which can take it away.
In proportion as the mind understands more things by the second and third kind of knowledge, it is less subject to those emotions which are evil, and stands in less fear of death.
Key Propositions.Significance: Higher knowledge reduces evil emotions and fear

Key Propositions.Statement: He, who possesses a body capable of the greatest number of activities, possesses a mind whereof the greatest part is eternal.
Key Propositions.Significance: Complex body implies more eternal mind

Key Propositions.Statement: In proportion as each thing possesses more of perfection, so is it more active, and less passive; and, vice versā, in proportion as it is more active, so is it more perfect.

Even if we did not know that our mind is eternal, we should still consider as of primary importance piety and religion, and generally all things which, in Part IV., we showed to be attributable to courage and high-mindedness.
Key Propositions.Significance: Importance of virtue regardless of eternity

Key Propositions.Statement: Blessedness is not the reward of virtue, but virtue itself; nor do we enjoy it because we restrain our lusts; on the contrary, because we enjoy it, we are able to restrain them
Key Propositions.Significance: Culmination: Intellectual love of God as eternal

key_aspects.reproductive_and_territorial_aggression: Bloom highlights how violence in animals often ties to reproduction and resource control, mirroring human conflicts. For instance, in gorillas and chimpanzees, groups engage in organized "warfare" against rivals, with males battling for territory and access to mates. Female primates, like baboons and gorillas, commit infanticide to prioritize their own offspring's dominance, dispelling the myth of inherent female pacifism. This parallels human history, where men wage wars and women (through sexual selection) reward aggressive "heroes," perpetuating cycles of violence driven by the urge to reproduce. Quote: "Under the impulse toward violence often lies the simple urge to have kids."
key_aspects.pecking_orders_and_hierarchies: A core axiom we discussed earlier (Axiom 5), the "pecking order" originates from observations of chickens, where dominance hierarchies determine access to food, mates, and survival. Bloom extends this to monkeys, wasps, and even nations, showing how lower-ranked individuals or groups struggle or perish. In humans, this manifests as social and political despotism, where ideologies justify dominance and lead to violence against "inferiors" or rivals. For example, high-ranking groups attract allies and resources, while low-ranking ones face elimination—echoing historical conquests like those of Rome or Carthage.
key_aspects.superorganisms_and_group_dynamics: Humans, like bees in a hive, form "superorganisms" where individual expendability serves the collective. Bloom describes male animals (and humans) as disposable in evolutionary terms, sacrificed in competitions or wars to manage population and resources. This "hypersociality" drives group-level violence, as seen in chimpanzee raids or human tribal conflicts. Quote: "Evolution is not just a competition between individuals. It is a competition between networks, between webs, between group souls."
key_aspects.broader_biological_imperatives: Bloom argues that nature itself is built on savagery—e.g., predators in ecosystems or competitive mating in species like lions—making violence a tool for innovation and adaptation. In humans, this translates to bigotry, warfare, and cultural clashes as extensions of animal territoriality and resource hoarding.

theLuciferPrinciple.evaluation_against_spinoza: Howard Bloom's view of violence as biologically ingrained contrasts with Spinoza's rationalist framework, where aggression arises from "passions" (inadequate ideas) rather than inherent evil. Spinoza sees humans as modes of Nature/God, striving for self-preservation (*conatus*, Part 3, Prop. 6), but violence stems from external causes and confused ideas leading to contrariety (Part 4, Prop. 34: "In so far as men are assailed by emotions which are passions, they can be contrary one to another"). Animal parallels align with Spinoza's determinism—all follows necessarily from Nature (Part 1, Prop. 29)—but Spinoza offers emancipation through reason, turning passions into active affects for harmony (Part 5, Prop. 3: "An emotion, which is a passion, ceases to be a passion, as soon as we form a clear and distinct idea thereof"). Bloom's evolutionary lens treats violence as unavoidable for progress, while Spinoza views it as bondage overcome by intellectual love of God/Nature (Part 5, Prop. 36).
theLuciferPrinciple.closing_note: This biological perspective strengthens the "steel man" by grounding abstract axioms in empirical animal studies, making arguments more robust against critiques of human exceptionalism. Web search to expand as needed.

Fallacies Forbidden.Ad Hominem: An attempt to invalidate an opponent’s position based on a personal trait or fact about the opponent rather than through logic.
Fallacies Forbidden.Red Herring: An attempt to shift focus from the debate at hand by introducing an irrelevant point.
Fallacies Forbidden.Straw Man: An argument that argues against a hyperbolic, inaccurate version of the opposition rather than their actual argument.
Fallacies Forbidden.Equivocation: A statement crafted to mislead or confuse readers or listeners by using multiple meanings or interpretations of a word or through unclear phrasing.
Fallacies Forbidden.Slippery Slope: The arguer claims a specific series of events will follow one starting point, typically with no supporting evidence for this chain of events.
Fallacies Forbidden.Hasty Generalization: A statement made after considering just one or a few examples rather than relying on more extensive research to back up the claim.
Fallacies Forbidden.Appeal to Authority: The arguer claims an authority figure’s expertise to support a claim despite this expertise being irrelevant or overstated.
Fallacies Forbidden.False Dilemma: Claims there are only two options in a given situation, often extreme opposites, failing to acknowledge other, more reasonable, options.
Fallacies Forbidden.Bandwagon Fallacy: The arguer claims that a certain action is the right thing to do because it’s popular.
Fallacies Forbidden.Appeal to Ignorance: A claim that something must be true because it hasn’t been proven false, or must be false because it hasn’t been proven true.
Fallacies Forbidden.Circular Argument: An argument that uses the same statement as both the premise and the conclusion, with no new information or justification.
Fallacies Forbidden.Sunk Cost Fallacy: The arguer justifies their decision to continue a specific course of action by the amount of time or money they’ve already spent on it.
Fallacies Forbidden.Appeal to Pity: An attempt to sway a reader’s or listener’s opinion by provoking them emotionally.
Fallacies Forbidden.Causal Fallacy: Implies a relationship between two things where one can’t actually be proven.
Fallacies Forbidden.Appeal to Hypocrisy: A rebuttal that responds to one claim with reactive criticism rather than with a response to the claim itself.
Fallacies Forbidden.Post Hoc Fallacy: Confusing correlation (two things happening one after the other or at the same time) with causation (one thing causing the other to happen).
Fallacies Forbidden.Fallacy of Composition: Assuming that something true of part of a whole must also be true of the whole.
Fallacies Forbidden.Fallacy of Division: Assuming that something true of a composite thing must also be true of all or some of its parts.
Fallacies Forbidden.Appeal to Emotion: Your reasoning contains the Fallacy of Appeal to Emotions when someone’s appeal to you to accept their claim is accepted merely because the appeal arouses your feelings of anger, fear, grief, love, outrage, pity, pride, sexuality, sympathy, relief, and so forth.
Fallacies Forbidden.Ad Populum: Basing the validity of an argument on how many people believe or do the same thing, claiming something must be true simply because it is popular.
Fallacies Forbidden.Tu Quoque: Avoiding having to engage with criticism by turning it back on the accuser - answering criticism with criticism.
Fallacies Forbidden.False Equivalence: Describing two or more statements as virtually equal when they are not.
Fallacies Forbidden.Etymological Fallacy: Assuming that the original or historical meaning of a word or phrase is necessarily similar to its actual present-day usage.
Fallacies Forbidden.Ecological Fallacy: Inferring about the nature of an entity based solely upon aggregate statistics collected for the group to which that entity belongs.
Fallacies Forbidden.Argument from Incredulity: When someone can't imagine something to be true, and therefore deems it false, or conversely, holds that it must be true because they can't see how it could be false.

InfantCircumcision_UnstoppableForce.introduction: Infant circumcision, performed without consent, constitutes a violation of bodily autonomy, causing irreversible physical and potential psychological harm. While rooted in religious and cultural traditions, it clashes with modern ethical standards emphasizing consent and harm minimization. This steel man argument highlights the procedure's harms and the unsolvable dilemma: for some, it is an essential covenantal rite; for others, an unacceptable infringement on individual rights. Organizations like Doctors Opposing Circumcision and Intact America advocate against it, viewing it as unnecessary and harmful in non-therapeutic contexts. The feedback praises this as a formidable grand theory with superior explanatory power.

Studies indicate this can lead to reduced penile sensitivity and potential issues like erectile dysfunction or chronic pain from scarring. Complications occur in approximately 0.2% to 0.6% of cases, including minor issues like bleeding or infection, with severe complications being rare but possible. The foreskin provides natural protective and lubricating functions; its removal can result in keratinization of the glans and altered biomechanics. Long-term, some men report diminished sexual function and intimacy, though evidence varies.
InfantCircumcision_UnstoppableForce.emotional_damage: The procedure elevates cortisol levels, indicating acute stress, which may disrupt early mother-infant bonding and contribute to attachment issues. Research links it to long-term effects like PTSD, altered pain sensitivity, stress disorders, and reduced emotional stability. Perceived as an aggressive attack, it can lead to feelings of damage, mistrust, withdrawal, weakened ego, and increased aggression. Anecdotal and study reports describe violation, loss, resentment, potentially causing depression or body image concerns. It correlates with higher aggression scores, parent-child aggression, and predisposition to ADD/ADHD or suicidal tendencies. While multifactorial (e.g., economics, politics), evidence positions it as a significant contributor in cultural contexts, desensitizing to harm and normalizing violence, supported by psychological models of early trauma leading to long-term behavioral changes. This mediates broader societal aggression patterns, though not sole cause; specificity tested via controlled studies on circumcised cohorts, addressing 'why now' through emerging data accessibility.
InfantCircumcision_UnstoppableForce.cycle_of_violence: Circumcision perpetuates intergenerational harm through cultural repetition, where trauma imprints lead to endorsement of the practice, creating normalized intervention. This 'hurt people hurt people' dynamic, seen in ritual contexts, rationalizes risks despite evidence, heightening ethical tensions. InfantCircumcision_UnstoppableForce.conclusion: As non-therapeutic, infant circumcision prioritizes tradition over autonomy, but ethical arguments assert bodily integrity trumps religious freedom for minors, per human rights and gender equity. While pluralistic, evidence of harms and historical dominance role warrant abolition or delay until consent, fostering empathy and rights-based societies.
